School of Chemical Engineering Northwest University Xi'an Shaanxi 710069 PR China The solvent-free synthesis of MOF represents a promising and environmentally benign protocol. This paper outlines a green one-pot mechanochemical method for the synthesizing of UiO-66 in the absence of solvent, along with the implantation of three different metals (Cu, Ni, and Pd) into the defect sites. The materials have proven to be effective catalysts in the transformation between azidocarbonate and amines/anilines in moderate to excellent isolated yields (up to 94%), exhibiting better advantages compared with the exiting methodologies. More interestingly, Cu and Ni exhibited very good catalytic performance towards primary and secondary amines, respectively. It also should be noted that high yield was still observed after six cycles. Our work presents a novel and straightforward strategy for the preparation of secondary and tertiary carbamates in an unprecedented fashion, greatly enriched the toolbox for the synthetic community. Moreover, the combination of experimental studies and density functional theory (DFT) calculations gave more insight and evidence for the mechanism. Accompanied by the advantages of the effective and recyclable catalyst, the broad substrate scope, good functional group tolerance, and excellent reaction yields made the established method attractive in heterogeneous catalysis and the carbamates synthesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Organic azide Metal-organic frameworks Carbamate Copper Nickel Mechanistic study Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbamates, especially those containing two or three substituents on the nitrogen atom, are a crucial group of compounds in chemical industry [1]. Among them, tertiary carbamates find extensively use in insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, drug design, and wide application as key intermediates in medicinal chemistry [1,2]. Therefore, considerable attention has been paid to prepare carbamates through the construction of C−N bonds. Current established strategies are mainly focused on two aspects. Firstly, catalytic difuntionalization of CO2 with amines and alcohols (or alkyl halide) [3]. However, most of them rely on the in situ generation of carbamate anions from CO2 and amines, followed by reactions with other coupling partners. Secondly, interrupted Hofmann rearrangement involved benzamides, bromine source (eg. Br2 or N-bromosuccinimide), as well as alcohosl via a phenyl isocyanate intermediate, followed by a reductive carbonylation (Scheme 1 a). Apart from the requirements of toxic reagents, high reaction pressure, the reactions are normally suffering from low regioselectivity (eg. funtionalization of CO2) which would lead to difficulties in product purification and restrict their application in chemical industry [4]. And yet, unfathomably, the similar phenomenon was existed in nearly all the aforementioned approaches, in which second amines were unable to participate in the reaction to form tertiary carbamates. Up to now, organic azides have been well documented in synthetic communities [5,6]. In contrast to conventional strategies, there are only limited reports concerning carbamates synthesis. In a distinguished work by Kim and co-workers, azidoformate was successfully introduced to generate N-aryl carbamates under homogeneous copper catalysis [7]. However, due to the nature of the Chan−Lam reaction, this methodology only enables the reaction of phenyl boronic acid and its aromatic derivatives, with the product restricted in secondary carbamates (Scheme 1b) [8,9]. Effective approaches to access these compounds starting from secondary amines is still a great challenge. Therefore, it is a highly interest to develop a novel and straightforward methodology to prepare carbamates in both secondary and tertiary form with different substituents on the nitrogen side besides aryls. Recently, we are concentrated our efforts to investigate efficient transformation of phosphoryl azides [10–14], sulfonyl azides [15], as well as azidoformates [8]. It should be noted that, copper species, no matter what the form is (eg. copper salt for homogeneous catalysis, supported copper catalyst and copper single atoms for heterogeneous catalysis) normally represents moderate to excellent catalytic activities towards the N2 release during the azide degradation process. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are highly porous materials where metal and secondary structural units connect through organic linkers [16,17]. Notably, their high specific surface area gives them a wide range of applications [18–24] and the tunable defect structure could provide many potential coordination sites for metal species [25,26]. These materials are typically synthesized through solvothermal methods with commendable morphology and crystallinity but necessitate considerable solvent employment [27]. The development of solvent-free and waste-free synthesis of MOF has been proposed in recent years [25,28]. Among them, inorganic solid-solid synthesis by ball milling stands out to be a suitable alternative and has a high potential for industrial scale-up [29].On the basis of our experience on organic azide transformations, it seems reasonable to design a MOF skeleton bearing active metal species to fulfill the requirements. Herein, we disclose a method for modifying metal active sites on the UiO-66 framework in-situ in a solvent-free fashion. By take advantage of the heterogeneous catalysts, secondary and tertiary carbamates were readily accessed from azide formates and primary (e.g. n-propylamine, cyclopropylamine, aniline) and secondary amines (e.g. diethylamine, pyrrole, purine), respectively. Our strategy was promoted by copper and nickel centers though absolute selective bond cleavage and formation processes, exhibiting better advantages compared with the exiting alternatives (Scheme 1c). The feasibility of this method and reaction pathway were demonstrated through density function theory (DFT) calculations. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Materials All reagents and reactants were procured from Energy Chemical (Shanghai) and used as received. Technical grade solvents for extraction and chromatography (ethyl acetate, petroleum ether, and diethyl ether) were distilled prior to use and other solvents were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Instrumentation methods The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by a powder X-ray diffractometer (SmartLAB SE, Rigaku). The micromorphology of the heterogeneous catalyst was observed via scanning electron microscope (SEM, Carl Zeiss SIGMA). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with a Thermo Fisher Scientific Nexsa™ instrument equipped with an Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1s peak at 284.5 eV. Peak fitting was performed by using XPSPEAK software with Shirley background. The actual metallic contents of catalysts was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on an Agillent 700DV instrument. 50 mg of sample was first digested (in a mixture of HNO3, HF, and H2SO4) for 2 h. Then, aliquots of solution were diluted to 250 mL using deionized water. The diluted samples were introduced into the instrument and the area of the spectra obtained were correlated to the concentration (thereby element content in wt%) using a 5-point calibration curve in the range of 1−10 ppm. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Frontier-PerkinElmer FT-IR spectrophotometer equipped with an ATR unit with BaSO4 as a reference and were reported in wavenumbers (cm−1). Analytical thinlayer chromatography (TLC) was performed on silica gel GF254 glass plates from Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Lt. Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel (300−400 mesh) by Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Lt using the indicated solvents. 1H, 13C NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl3 on Bruker Avance III 400 MHz instrument. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed on a Fuli 9790II gas chromatography equipped with a KB-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm, 0.25 μm film thickness) by Fuli and high pure nitrogen as a carrier gas with flame ionization detector. Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH STA449C instrument loaded with 5 mg sample using a heating rate of 5°C/min under argon atmosphere. 2.3 Procedures for the preparation of UiO-66 catalysts 2.3.1 Solvent-free synthesis of UiO-66 ZrOCl2∙8H2O (1.5 mmol, 483.4 mg) and benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC, 1.5 mmol, 249.2 mg) were mixed in planetary ball mill (PBM) and ground for 10 min at room temperature. The obtained mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130°C for 8 h. Finally, the obtained materials were washed twice with 20 mL acetone and then dried at 150°C for 12h. The final product was denoted as UiO-66. 2.3.2 Solvent-free synthesis of Cu/UiO-66 ZrOCl2∙8H2O (1.5 mmol, 483.4 mg) and BDC (1.5 mmol, 249.2 mg) were mixed in planetary ball mill and ground for 3 min at room temperature. After that, 0.25 mmol CuCl was added and the system was further ground for 10 min. The obtained mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130°C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solids were washed successively with 20 mL fresh ethanol (once) to remove the un-reacted CuCl, 50 mL ethanol (4 times) to remove the un-reacted reactants, and 20 mL acetone (once). Finally, the obtained materials were dried at 150°C for 12 h and the final product was denoted as Cu/UiO-66. 2.3.3 Solvent-free synthesis of Ni/UiO-66 ZrOCl2∙8H2O (1.5 mmol, 483.4 mg) and BDC (1.5 mmol, 249.2 mg) were mixed in planetary ball mill and ground for 3 min at room temperature. After that, 0.25 mmol NiCl2 was added and the system was further ground for 10 min. The obtained mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130°C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solids were washed successively with 20 mL fresh ethanol (once) to remove the un-reacted NiCl2, 50 mL ethanol (4 times) to remove the un-reacted reactants, and 20 mL acetone (once). Finally, the obtained materials were dried at 150°C for 12 h and the final product was denoted as Ni/UiO-66. 2.3.4 Solvent-free synthesis of Pd/UiO-66 ZrOCl2∙8H2O (1.5 mmol, 483.4 mg) and BDC (1.5 mmol, 249.2 mg) were mixed in planetary ball mill and ground for 3 min at room temperature. After that, 0.25 mmol PdCl2 was added and the system was further ground for 10 min. The obtained mixture was transferred into a 20 mL Teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave and crystallized at 130°C for 8 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solids were washed successively with 20 mL fresh ethanol (once) to remove the un-reacted PdCl2, 50 mL ethanol (4 times) to remove the un-reacted reactants, and 20 mL acetone (once). Finally, the obtained materials were dried for 12 h at 150°C and the final product was denoted as Pd/UiO-66. 2.4 General procedure for the synthesis of alkyl/aryl carbamates The azide carboxylate (0.50 mmol, 1.0 equiv.), amine (1.00 mmol, 2.0 equiv.), M/UiO-66 (40 mg), and solvent (2.0 mL) were added successively to a flame-dried Schlenk tube fitted with a magnetic stir bar. The reaction mixture was stirred at the specified temperature and for specified time. After the reaction was completed, the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered. The solids were collected, washed with DCE, dried in an oven, and stored for further catalytic reaction. The filtrate was diluted with 25 mL of ethyl acetate and washed with 5 mL of H2O. The organic phase was combined and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated under reduced pressure. The product was purified by flash column chromatography using a silica gel column and a mixture of petroleum ether and ethyl acetate as eluents. The resulting product was obtained as analytically pure. 3 Results and discussion Firstly, a planetary ball mill was employed to prepare catalysts through a one-pot solvent-free methodology. ZrOCl2·8H2O, BDC, and the corresponding metal chloride were used respectively, which were ground together in a ball mill and then added to an autoclave to crystallize at 130°C for 8 h. XRD (Fig. 1a ) showed that all three catalysts were obtained to a reasonable degree of crystallization and had the same UiO-66 diffraction peaks as those prepared by the hydrothermal method [26]. And no crystallization peaks of metal salts were observed in X-ray diffraction, which was a good indication that the loaded metals are uniformly distributed in the MOF skeleton at this stage. It demonstrated that the catalysts can be successfully and readily accessed by the one-pot solvent-free process of ball milling. In order to further explore the structural properties of the catalysts, we carried out FT-IR characterization as illustrated in Fig. 1b. It can be seen that these three catalysts showed very similar characteristic peaks, while character peaks of metal salts were not observed at all, indicated that the loaded metals were uniformly distributed in the catalysts [30–33]. Among them, the absorption band at 1560 cm−1 and 1660 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of C−C and C−O bonds, while the peak at 570 cm−1 is mainly attributed to the vibration of Zr−O bond. TGA analysis under nitrogen environment showed that Cu/UiO-66 and Ni-UiO-66 had similar heat loss curves, whereas the heat loss curve of Pd/UiO-66 was relatively more gentle (Fig. 1c). However, in general, the heat loss of these catalysts from room temperature to 400°C is close to 30%, and this value reaches quickly to nearly 50% at 550°C before the catalyst structure was completely destroyed. This phenomenon fully reflected that these catalysts representing strong thermal stability below 400°C. The chemical compositions of the catalysts were further identified by ICP-OES and the loading content of Cu, Ni, and Pd in the heterogeneous materials was estimated to be 6.7%, 5.4%, and 6.4%, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted to analyze the chemical composition and chemical status of the elements of all as-prepared M/UiO-66. As presented in Fig. 1d, the survey spectra exhibited prominent binding energy peaks of Cu 2p, clearly indicating the coexistence of Cu2+ and Cu+ species on the surface of both samples. The high-resolution Cu 2p XPS spectrum revealed two major peaks at 931.08 eV and 951.28 eV, corresponding to the Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 states of the Cu+ species, respectively. Additionally, distinct peaks located at 932.78 eV (Cu 2p3/2) and 953.58 eV (Cu 2p 1/2) were observed, confirming the presence of Cu2+ species. The occurrence of Cu2+ can be attributed to the oxidation of Cu+ during catalyst preparation when exposed to air. As shown in Figs. 1e and S1, the survey XPS spectrum of Ni/UiO-66 indicated the coexistence of Ni, C, O, and Zr elements. The corresponding high-resolution Ni 2p XPS spectrum featured two major peaks at 856.98 and 874.58 eV, which can be attributed to the Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 of the Ni2+ species (Fig. 1e). In addition, several satellite peaks were observed at about 859.98, 863.68, 879.88, and 883.78 eV (Fig. 1e). The results are consistent with the Ni signals previously reported for immobilized Ni-based complexes. Fig. 1f displayed the high-resolution Pd 3d XPS spectrum. On the one hand, a major peak at the binding energy of 333.28 eV was probably attributed to the 3d 3/2 of the Pd2+ species. On the other hand, the strong peak positioned at 346.78 eV can be attributed to the Pd 2p 1/2 of the Pd2+ species. The Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) characterization (Fig. 2 ) reveals that the specific surface area of UiO-66 is 1095.6629 m2/g, whereas that of Cu/UiO-66 is slightly reduced to 876.4582 m2/g, indicating a slight decrease in the specific surface area of the Cu-supported catalyst. Additionally, the micropore volume decreased from 0.70 cm3/g to 0.67 cm3/g, suggesting the successful loading of Cu into the MOF pores. Furthermore, the acid-base potentiometric titration experiments were conducted to calculate the number of missing linkers (please refer to the Fig. S4 and Tables S2−S4 in detail). In UiO-66 and Cu/UiO-66, there are 2.05 and 1.88 per Zr-oxo clusters respectively, resulting in a reduction of 0.17 missing connections per Zr-oxo cluster in Cu/UiO-66 compared to UiO-66 (-OH/OH2) . This reduction corresponds to a decrease of 0.68 defect sites per Zr-oxo cluster and further confirms that Cu occupies defect sites within the MOF structure as Zr−O−Cu. In order to further determine the morphology of the material, scanning electron microscopy for all the catalysts were carried out. It can be seen in Fig. 3 , these catalysts exist in the form of flakes with relatively uniform sizes, which is quite different from the UiO-66 with a classical ortho-octahedron configuration obtained through hydrothermal method. Preliminary conclusions can be drawn out that it seems difficult to make the crystallization of MOF into a more regular morphology through solvent-free approaches [29]. Initially, the catalytic condition optimization process was started by employing benzyl azidocarbonate (1a) as substrate and primary amine n-propylamine (2b) as a conventional nucleophilic reagent (Fig. 4 ). However, the reaction failed to proceed either in the absence of catalyst or by using Cu/UiO-66 alone as catalyst without anchoring transition metals as active centers. We then turned our attention to evaluate the catalytic activities of the newly prepared heterogeneous catalysts, Cu/UiO-66, Ni/UiO-66, and Pd/UiO-66 in this protocol. Much to our delight, desired product 3aa were obtained in all cases in isolated yields ranging from 43−64% after 3 h in dichloroethane system, with Cu/UiO-66 being the highest. Based on these achievements, we then explored the effect of different reaction medium on the reaction. As shown, DCE has emerged as the solvent of choice with excellent yield, whlle other candidates such as cyclohexane, acetonitrile, or acetone gave rise to lower results (Fig. 4a). Encouragingly, nearly full conversion and 94% yield were afforded where prolonged reaction time was required (3 h → 6h), however, further extending the reaction time was not helpful (12 h, Fig. 4b). Subsequently, the amount of catalyst was also determined, increase the catalyst loading did not result in obviously increasement of yield (94% and 95% for 40 mg and 60 mg of Cu/UiO-66, respectively), while reduce catalyst usage by half led to a remarkable decreasement (87% for 20 mg of Cu/UiO-66). Considering the compatibility of the catalytic system, we chose diethylamine and pyrrole as representatives of secondary amines for further identification of the reaction conditions. The reaction temperature was also an important parameter, while catalysis conducted either at ambient or elevated reaction temperatures were considered to be detrimental, with slightly reduced yield or even accompanied by several by-products and complex catalytic system. The best results for all of them were observed at 40 °C, which were 94%, 53%, and 58%, respectively (Fig. 4c). Unfortunately, it seems like that second amines were less reactive. We envisioned that the intermediate formed with the decomposition of azide group promoted by Cu centre might be inefficiently in dehydrogen-coupling with the secondary amine. According to the known reports [34,35], Ni and Pd generally performed better in the dehydrogenation couplings of secondary amines. To verify our hypothesis, Ni/UiO-66 and Pd/UiO-66 were introduced in the identical catalytic systems as a comparison. Not surprisingly, both of them demonstrated to be much more effective, furthermore, the catalysts presented different catalytic activities against secondary amines compared with primary nucleophiles (Fig. 4d). It is noteworthy that Ni/UiO-66 showed a significant increase in 90% and 87% yield for both diethylamine (1b) and pyrrole (1c) respectively, which was in agreement with the literature concerning the Ni-catalyzed C−N bond formation reactions [35]. Under optimised catalytic conditions, we further investigated azidocarbonates and amines with different substituents (Scheme 2 ). For primary amines, they all reacted smoothly, provided the desired products in moderate to excellent yields (3aa−3am). Overall, good yields (94%) could be achieved for short chain aliphatic amines (3aa and 3ab). Interestingly, tert-butylamine (3af) and Isobutylamine (3ae) gave rise to 62% and 80% isolated yield, respectively, while the huge difference was largely attributed to the sterichindrance of the former nucleophile. This is closely related to the nucleophilicity of the amines and the reactivity of these three amines decreases with nucleophilicity. Surprisingly, moderate yields of 63% or more were still achieved for high carbon amines (e.g. tetradecylamine). Steric effects also had a significant impact on the reactivity, with cyclopropylamine, cyclobutylamine, and cyclohexylamine showing decreasing results, suggesting that the reaction may involve the expression of the SN2 pathway. The reaction of azide reagents with aniline has not been illustrated in the literature so far due to the strong attenuation of the nucleophilicity compared with fatty amines. We conducted the reactions by using both aniline and its derivative as substrates and were pleased to find that both gave moderate yields (4aa−4ab). Strikingly, we then investigated azocarbamates and secondary amines, heteroazoaliphatics (e.g. heteroazocyclobutane) and heteroazoaromatics (e.g. pyrrole), which were rarely employed in the preparation of carbamates, exhibited good tolerance in our experimental setup with yields over 50% (5aa−5ad). Subsequently, several azocarbonate compounds with different functional groups were also evaluated under the optimized reaction conditions and all of them were able to carry out the amination of propylamine, leading to moderate to good yields of the desired products. It can be clearly seen that the yields of the electron-donating substituents (6ab−6ad) were significantly higher than those substrates containing electron-withdrawing groups (6ae−6af). Firstly, the structural stability of the catalyst was investigated by DFT calculation [36]. In the process of catalyst preparation, the substitution of Cu for C8H5O2 3+ is considered to be competitive with the substitution of Cu for Zr (Fig. 5 ). In chemical thermodynamics, when temperature and pressure are constant, the non-volume work is zero, and the thermal more reaction free energy (Δr Gm ) of the process being less than zero, the reaction could be proceeded spontaneously. As illustrated in Formulas (1) and (2), Δr Gm is obtained by the sum of the free energy (Gm ) of the products minus the sum of the free energy of the reactants at 298.15 K under 1.0 atm. On the one hand, based on the decoration protocol (R1), Δr Gm ,1 is calculated to be -834.28 kcal·mol−1, demonstrated that the replacement of C8H5O2 3+ by Cu2+ is a thermodynamically favorite process (Fig. 5a). On the other hand, according to the replacement reaction (R2), Δr Gm ,2 is calculated to be as high as 9087.27 kcal·mol−1, expressly indicated that the replacement of Zr by Cu is highly thermodynamically unfavorable (Fig. 5a). UiO − 66 + C u 2 + = Cu / UiO − 66 − + C 8 H 5 O 2 3 + R 1 UiO − 66 + C u 2 + = Cu / UiO − 66 ( 5 Zr ) 2 − + Z r 4 + R 2 (1) Δ r G m , 1 = G m , C u / U i O − 66 − + G m , C 8 H 5 O 2 3 + − G m , U i O − 66 − G m , C u 2 + (2) Δ r G m , 2 = G m , C u / U i O − 66 ( 5 Z r ) 2 − + G m , Z r 4 + − G m , U i O − 66 − G m , C u 2 + DFT calculation was conducted to gain a better understanding of the role that the implantation of Cu in UiO-66 skeleton on the transformation. To show the different reaction activity between them and propylamine, the frontier molecular orbitals (the highest occupied molecular orbital: HOMO and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital: LUMO), which play key roles in chemical reactions, were calculated [37]. The HOMO and LUMO of UiO-66 distributed uniformly and symmetrically throughout the whole molecule, while the HOMO of Cu/UiO-66 is mainly distributed on the Cu−Cl group (Fig. 6 ). According to the frontier orbital theory, when UiO-66 and Cu/UiO-66 react with n-propylamine, the electrons in the HOMO of UiO-66 and Cu/UiO-66 flow to the LUMO of n-propylamine. As shown by the calculation, the HOMO of Cu/UiO-66 (-5.03 eV) are obviously closer to the LUMO of propylamine (1.09 eV) (6.12 ev for Fig. 6 right) compared with UiO-66 (HOMO: -7.67 eV) (8.76 ev for Fig. 6 left). Therefore, Cu/UiO-66 has a higher potential and tendency to react with propylamine than UiO-66, thus endowing it with superior catalytic activity. After that, we attempted to investigate more evidence that Cu/UiO-66 had better applicability to fatty primary amines and Ni/UiO-66 performed better on secondary amines with the aid of DFT calculations. It is well known that the electronic properties of the metal active sites may have different degrees of influence on the reaction. Moreover, for the catalysts (M/UiO-66, M = metal) prepared in this paper, charge transfer usually occurred between metal and its carrier UiO-66, which might significantly change the electronic properties of the metal catalytic site. Therefore, exploring charge transfers between metal and UiO-66 would be helpful to explore the reaction mechanism. After computational analysis, Ni has the largest charge transfer value (0.63 |e|) to the frame, while Cu and Pd had the value of 1.16 |e| and 0.86 |e|, respectively [38]. A large amount of charge transferring from MOF skeleton to the metal indicated that the metal centers are more electron deficient, suggesting that they can be considered as stronger Lewis acid sites [38]. In addition, different metal oxidation states could alter the adsorption energy towards the substrate, and thus to realize higher catalytic activities. Therefore, we calculated the adsorption energies of the three catalysts for n-propylamine and pyrrole, respectively (Table 1 ). It is obvious to see that Ni represented the strongest adsorption energy for secondary amines such as pyrrole (-68.605 kcal mol−1) and diethylamine (-69.499 kcal mol−1), while Cu displayed a stronger value for n-propylamine (-80.669 kcal mol−1). The higher adsorption energy means that the reaction is more likely to occur, which was consistent with the experimental results. To further investigate the application of this protocol, the recyclability of the Cu/UiO-66 in heterogeneous catalysis was discussed. Recycling tests on the indicated substrates 1a and 2b showed that the catalytic activity did not deteriorate significantly after six cycles (94% for the first run vs 85% for the sixth run, Fig. 7 ). Furthermore, ICP-OES characterisation revealed that the Cu content after six runs was 5.9%, which was correlated with the degradation of the catalytic activities. Accordingly, the reaction mechanism of copper catalyzed azide formates with amines was proposed in Scheme 3 . The metal-azido intermediate was generated in situ between the reaction of azide formates and [Cu] catalyst, followed by a SN2 type nucleophilic attack with the Amine compound. Afterwards, the desired carbamate was accomplished. At the same time, the released unstable [Cu−N3] species was decomposed immediately to regenerate [Cu] catalyst and deliver a N2 molecular. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, a simple and environmentally friendly procedure was introduced to synthesize M/UiO-66 with highly dispersed metal active sites under solvent-free mechanochemical conditions. Structural analysis indicated that the active metal sites are attached to the nodes of UiO-66 in a Zr−O−M fashion, which was supported by DFT calculations. Three different metals have been synthesized, including Cu/UiO-66 (Cu: 6.7%), Ni/UiO-66 (Ni: 5.4%), and Pd/UiO-66 (Pd: 6.4%). Cu/UiO-66 presented remarkable results for the reaction between azidocarbonate and primary amines, while Ni/UiO-66 has proven to be the best catalyst for the reaction of secondary amines. These catalysts enabled efficient coupling of C−N bonds and significantly broadened the carbamates scopes in secondary and tertiary derivatives. This novel protocol not only opens an avenue to design MOF based heterogeneous catalysts, but also provides more insight and evidence for the efficient synthesis of various secondary and tertiary carbamates with high reactivities. coredata.dc:description: The solvent-free synthesis of MOF represents a promising and environmentally benign protocol. This paper outlines a green one-pot mechanochemical method for the synthesizing of UiO-66 in the absence of solvent, along with the implantation of three different metals (Cu, Ni, and Pd) into the defect sites. The materials have proven to be effective catalysts in the transformation between azidocarbonate and amines/anilines in moderate to excellent isolated yields (up to 94%), exhibiting better advantages compared with the exiting methodologies. More interestingly, Cu and Ni exhibited very good catalytic performance towards primary and secondary amines, respectively. It also should be noted that high yield was still observed after six cycles. Our work presents a novel and straightforward strategy for the preparation of secondary and tertiary carbamates in an unprecedented fashion, greatly enriched the toolbox for the synthetic community. Moreover, the combination of experimental studies and density functional theory (DFT) calculations gave more insight and evidence for the mechanism. Accompanied by the advantages of the effective and recyclable catalyst, the broad substrate scope, good functional group tolerance, and excellent reaction yields made the established method attractive in heterogeneous catalysis and the carbamates synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: In situ-grown active transition metal-functionalized MOF via solvent-free mechanochemical conditions as effective catalyst for the preparation of carbamates from organic azides with amines and anilines
